title: Macro Live, FOMC edition
bodyHTML:
5:58 pm
MK

Howdy!

CG

Rabble, make yourselves known

CG

We've just had word that Donald Trump has bailed out of the next debate and FoxNews cancelled it

5:58 pm
CG

But he can't shut down Markets Live, which is ten times more exciting anyways

CG

Greetings Boncoeur, paver, Wilbon

CG

statement comes out in one minute

5:59 pm
MK

Cardiff, who do we think the Donald might want at the Federal Reserve Board? There are lots of openings

CG

If it's a big yawn, I blame Matt for taking all the suspense out of it with his excellent preview post earlier

MK

As a reminder, OIS pricing implies 3.4% chance they raise rates today

6:00 pm
CG

https://www.federa...tary/20160316a.htm

MK

Here are the projections http://www.federal...ojtabl20160316.pdf

CG

it's out -- no change to rates

6:01 pm
CG

"labor market conditions improved further even as economic growth slowed late last year"...

MK

outlook for Fed Funds rate significantly lower

MK

Median rate expectation for 2016 and 2017 about 50 bps lower than when surveyed in December

6:03 pm
CG

wowza, came down with a quickness

MK

Intriguingly, the shallower tightening path isn't being driven by changes in inflation, growth, or unemployment outlook

CG

I wonder how spooked they were by the initial reaction to the first hike

6:03 pm
CG

the financial market fluctuations in Jan and Feb

MK

It's an interesting question, especially since many things have mostly gotten back to where they were

MK

The median for the longer-run expectation of Fed funds is just 3.3 per cent

6:05 pm
MK

or about 1.3 per cent in real terms, after subtracting their 2 per cent inflation goal

MK

That's pretty low

CG

in any case, clear that Fed has moved towards the market more than the other way around

6:06 pm
MK

Ever since they started publishing the dots, the rule has switched from "Don't fight the Fed" to "Fight the Fed!"

MK

(The first dots came out in January, 2012. Median FOMC participant expected "normalization" to begin in 2014 and long-run FF to be 4.25%)

CG

labour market stronger + inflation picking up + ? = shallower path

6:07 pm
CG

curious to hear her explain the ?

MK

@SH you're welcome

MK

Incidentally, this really goes to demonstrate the significance of Brainard's presence on the Fed board

6:09 pm
MK

She is the most forceful critic of the Yellen/Fischer Phillips Curve hawks

CG

indeed

MK

Lots of weight on "However, global economic and financial developments continue to pose risks."

6:10 pm
CG

I'll be looking for more on exactly that in the presser

CG

thoughts on strong USD, expectation for sustained depressed energy prices (relative to prior expectation)

CG

https://twitter.com/lisaabramowicz1/status/710166592152330240

6:12 pm
MK

That's upside down!

CG

SH, I hate to scare you off but probably not

MK

But good, the Europeans shouldn't rely on good-natured Americans to bail them out of their own failures to boost domestic demand

6:14 pm
CG

Median expectation for PCE inflation this year is 1.2% headline (relative to 1.6% in December)

CG

For core it remains at 1.6%

CG

Latest core inflation readings have turned up a bit more than expected

6:15 pm
MK

Another interesting tidbit is their forecast for unemployment falling a bit more than they were forecasting in December

MK

The implied gap between their 2018 unemployment forecast and their "longer-run" unemployment forecast is particularly interesting

CG

I guess it implied the Fed would be willing to let the economy run "hot" temporarily (by its own definition of "hot", or unemployment below Nairu) to get inflation climbing

6:18 pm
CG

though obviously Nairu itself kind of an amorphous concept, and it's been lowered repeated in the past few years

MK

Right, back when Yellen was Vice Chairman, in 1996-7, she thought NAIRU was around 5.5%. Unemployment bottomed at 3.8% in 2000, and inflation was consistently slower than it was in 1996 the whole time.

MK

(For more on that http://ftalphavill...e-mistake-of-1998/ )

6:21 pm
MK

9 minute warning for the press conference

CG

Since we still have nine minutes to go before the presser, I'll get super-speculative and note that

CG

1) I think there's just as much of a chance that inflation surprises higher this year as lower -- not just because of energy, but also trends in shelter and medical prices, and

6:23 pm
CG

2) if (or when?) productivity growth ever jumps again, we might well have a Nairu is way lower than it is now (which pushes in the direction on inflation, of course). Either way, natural rate of anything as opaque a measure as ever

CG

https://twitter.com/ObsoleteDogma/status/710167594158968832

CG

This surprised me too

6:25 pm
CG

Thought it would be included

CG

could be that internal debate is really quite vigorous at the moment, committee wants to leave options open to the extent possible

MK

Despite the big downward revision to the FOMC Fed funds forecasts since December, their median projection is still a bit below what's implied by eurodollar futures prices as of this morning. 3.0% vs ~1.6% for the end of 2018, for example

6:27 pm
MK

Eurdollars seem to be roughly in line with the Fed for the end of this year, though

CG

you mean above

MK

Yes, sorry, Fed is above the market

6:29 pm
CG

markets still pricing in much shallower path

CG

np

MK

(This is why we edit each others' posts)

6:29 pm
CG

long way to go

CG

https://twitter.com/JustinWolfers/status/710166551970840576

CG

presser starting!

6:31 pm
MK

http://bcove.me/kq3gupe0

MK

Yellen leads off by talking about steady pace of job growth

CG

notes labor force participation rate bump of 0.5 percentage pointss

6:33 pm
MK

She also notes the increase in the labor participation rate, which suggests at least some of the decline since 2007 can be reversed if the economy continues to improve

CG

yep, a solid recent win for the labour market slack folks

MK

This is a direct rebuttal to the "it's all structural" camp, which blames things like aging and greater propensity to go to school for a massive decline in employment

6:33 pm
CG

(also, you know, Americans who want jobs)

MK

Now she's switching to business investment and net exports, which have been weak

CG

I'm expecting more talks than usual about trends abroad

6:35 pm
MK

"Once these transitory influences fade and the labor market strengthens further, the Committee expects inflation to rise to 2% over the next few years"

CG

dollar, energy, China, fluctuations from earlier this year

MK

"Stability of longer-run expectations cannot be taken for granted"

6:36 pm
CG

downplaying market-based inflation expectations without totally dismissing them a staple of the Yellen era

MK

@SH that's what she said, and that's what's in the forecast

MK

Whether it's accurate...

6:39 pm
MK

@SH yes it is, although recall Yellen is a big believer in the "long and variable lags" school http://ftalphavill...ou-think-it-means/

MK

"Neutral nominal Federal funds rate...is currently low by historical standards and is likely to rise only gradually over time. Attributable to a range of persistent economic headwinds: weakness abroad, subdued household formation, and weak productivity growth."

MK

"If these headwinds abate, neutral Federal funds rate should move higher as well"

6:42 pm
MK

As a reminder, the Laubach-Williams estimate of the "neutral" real FF rate is a bit below zero, right now

MK

Yellen saying FOMC has changed collective opinion of rate path required to generate same economic outcomes forecast back in December

MK

In particular, lower rates required to get same growth and inflation

6:44 pm
MK

I really hope we get an explanation of what could have changed so much in the past few months

CG

I'll say one thing: whatever you think of the Fed's recent decisions, the decision not to raise this time and the shallower path does add credibility to the claims that policy is data-dependent. A number of FOMC members still have an annoying habit of making calendar-based arguments in their public statements, but today's decision at least leans a bit the other way

MK

CG, agreed. They are flexible.

6:45 pm
CG

question time!

MK

Unfortunately, their reaction function(s) are a bit opaque.

MK

Question is: "if current conditions not good enough to raise rates, what would be?"

6:47 pm
CG

Median should not be interpreted as a committee-endorsed forecast. You want it to be one way, Steve, but it's the other way

CG

(reference to The Wire; I'll leave you to look it up)

CG

she's going with the non-answer answer here

5:58 pm
CG

Hello!

MK

Check out Figure 10 of this paper on the history of those optimistic forecasts http://www.frbsf.o...iles/wp2015-16.pdf

CG

Sam Fleming!

6:51 pm
CG

That would be the FT's very own Sam "Green Eggs & Ham" Fleming

CG

https://twitter.com/M_C_Klein/status/710176852497833984

MK

Question is about how to justify 2 rate hikes this year

6:55 pm
CG

the gradual move up is the result of the energy effect and prolonged stronger USD, she says

CG

with stronger labour market pushing the other way, of course

CG

Yellen nervous about getting behind the curve

6:55 pm
MK

Anyone in the rabble have a view on eurodollar futures? TIPS? Inflation swaps?

MK

"Chinese growth hasn't proven a great surprise"

MK

"Our neighbors to the north and south are feeling the impact of lower oil prices on their growth"

6:58 pm
MK

@guidinghand was hoping more for reactions to the announcement and press conference

CG

question about lower oil prices not translating into higher consumer spending

MK

Also asking if a modest bounce in oil (to $50) would have an impact on inflation that would merit a response

7:01 pm
MK

"It's very difficult, when you look at patterns of consumer spending...to definitely say that lower oil prices have not boost consumer spending...I'm not sure we can arrive at that conclusion in a rigorous way"

MK

Does this mean she thinks consumption growth would have slowed down in the absence of oil drop?

CG

"microdata on household spending patterns" - DRINK

7:02 pm
MK

"The committee has tended to look through movements in oil prices, whether on the upside or the downside"

CG

Londo, some of it, surely, and savings rates have climbed. Just takes a while to pass through to spending sometimes, especially if people wonder whether it will last. Could be other reasons as well, something new structural about spending, who knows!

MK

Question notes disappearance of "risks to the outlook" language since December move

7:04 pm
CG

People have mental models of spending, so some of it went into new cars and, as amir sufi pointed out to us not long ago, higher-priced premium gas (an amusing finding, though not significant enough)

MK

"What happens to get back to balanced?"

CG

"risks to the outlooks have diminished" but didn't want to make collective judgment on balance of risks in the statement

7:05 pm
MK

"There is no collective judgment in this statement on whether the risks are balanced or not. My guess is some participants see them as balanced, some see them weighted to the downside"

MK

Apparently none see risks weighted to the upside?

CG

I'm looking forward to the minutes of this meeting explaining the disagreement on this one

7:06 pm
MK

"The risks are not all one-sided"

CG

notes foreign central banks getting off their a$$es (she said it more eloquently than that)

MK

CG, interesting she doesn't seem to think those foreign central banks are attempting to boost growth through net exports to USA, otherwise she wouldn't be citing them as an upside risk

7:08 pm
MK

Yellen expects wage growth to accelerate, mostly based on employment data and anecdotes

CG

well, in that context I think she was noting the positive side is often ignored, not that the negative effect doesn't exist

CG

double-negatives for the win

7:10 pm
MK

"Every demographic group we track has seen improvement in their labor market situation"

MK

@EAO just means more purchasing power for Japanese firms to invest abroad

MK

teeth smile

7:13 pm
MK

Current question about rising importance of exchange rate channel and globalization of market forces

MK

"It's natural there should be some divergence in our monetary policies. Movements in exchange rates partly reflect that."

MK

"Our policy is not crippled just because there are these inter-linkages. That's just how the system works. It's why we meet with policymakers from other countries and exchange notes."

7:15 pm
MK

@Boncoeur I think the donation question was about this http://www.wsj.com...ampaign-1457456261

MK

A Federal Reserve governor donated to Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign in recent months, a rare sign of political favor by a member of the central bank’s powerful board.

Lael Brainard, who was nominated to the board by President Barack Obama, made three contributions totaling $750 between mid-November and mid-January, according to Federal Election Commission records. The donations were earlier reported by Bloomberg News.

The contributions didn’t violate any central-bank rules, a Fed spokeswoman said. Fed board members can make campaign donations but are barred from engaging in partisan political activities, in line with rules that apply to the executive branch. When asked if Ms. Brainard would comment, a Fed spokesman said, “We have nothing more for you.”

CG

Binya of the NYt

7:17 pm
MK

The question is why the path of rate increases has become lower and shallower

MK

And if this reflects greater slack in the labor market because LFPR might go back up

CG

shallower path reflects lower estimates for the long term rate

7:17 pm
CG

she says

MK

Question about vacancies on the Fed board and the failure to nominate anyone for the Vice-Chairman of supervision, which has been empty for several years

CG

indeed

7:18 pm
MK

"Congress intended for the Federal Reserve Board to have 7 members"

CG

Don't nominate an idiot

MK

"Regarding the Vice chair of supervision, that's a question you'd have to ask the White House"

7:19 pm
CG

That's just common sense

MK

"Do you share concern that not enough has been done in changing the regulatory landscape of banking?"

MK

(Question from journalist at American Banker)

7:20 pm
CG

more and higher quality capital, more liquidity in the banking system, changes in supervision like the stress tests

CG

if we're not awesome, we're certainly awesomer than we used to be

MK

"Quantum leap in quality of supervision"

7:21 pm
MK

This doesn't answer the question of whether enough has been done, just that some things have been done

MK

"We've made very substantial progress. A month or so ago we came out with the TLAC rule. Hold a substantial buffer of long-term debt that could get bailed in."

MK

"Hold" is a poor choice of words

7:23 pm
CG

https://twitter.com/pdacosta/status/710184555060318210

MK

Follow up question: "why haven't these improvements made their way to the public? why do people think nothing has changed?"

MK

Question is about whether Yellen believes in the Phillips Curve

7:24 pm
CG

Phillips Curve -- drink!

MK

"There's a relationship between the degree of slack in the labor market and the rate of inflation...there's an empirical relationship. I believe that relationship still holds"

MK

"Estimates of Phillips Curve quite flat"

7:26 pm
CG

Phillips Curve theory says inflation expectations matter for wage- and price-setting behavior, which is why they're highlighted in the fomc statements

MK

https://twitter.com/BenLeubsdorf/status/710185586997403648/photo/1

MK

Question is about negative rates vs QE for next recession

7:29 pm
MK

"This is not actively a subject we are considering or discussing"

CG

do we know if they would be legal or not yet?

CG

that seems like something the fed should figure out

7:29 pm
MK

Cumulative probability of recession rises to 100% on long enough time horizon

MK

"If we found ourselves in the unlikely situation where we'd need to add accommodation, we have the tools. We could extend the maturity of our portfolio, asset purchases, forward guidance..."

MK

"Negative rates is not something we would actively consider"

7:30 pm
MK

And with that, mic drop

CG

DONE

MK

Yellen out

7:31 pm
CG

okay Matt, takeaways?

CG

My two are:

CG

1) Clear demonstrations of willingness to be flexible, data-dependent, regardless of how confusing their public statements often are on the data-dependence vs calendar-based argument

7:32 pm
CG

2) Buried underneath all this is profound uncertainty about the outlook for growth and (especially) inflation

CG

hence not including the balance of risks language, and yellen implying during the presser that views quite mixed

CG

you?

7:34 pm
MK

Definitely agree there's a severe tension between the goals of flexibility, transparency, and diversity of opinion within the FOMC. The more debate there is internally, the harder it is to be transparent about what people are actually thinking. Hence Yellen's comments about balance of risks, the ambiguity about what's driving the changes in the inflation forecasts and the short-rate forecasts, etc.

MK

The simplest takeaway is the fact they think a much shallower hike path is now required to achieve same mix of economic outcomes, and that they figured this out in about 3 months.

MK

Why they feel this way, is unclear

7:35 pm
MK

Also we should note the return of hawkish dissenters, after a brief absence

CG

flexibility + lack of perceived reaction function = little visibility. All that said, a clearly dovish move today, where dovish is defined by probability of reaction function tolerating lower unemployment than before

CG

and tolerating defined as

7:36 pm
MK

@Boncoeur, markets tanked but then rebounded

MK

Most things back to where they were

CG

"before tightening as previously communicated"

7:37 pm
CG

equities doing well today, haven't checked treasuries

MK

@Boncoeur HY spreads way down too

CG

okay everyone, thanks for joining us, we're shutting down now, see you next time!

7:43 pm
MK

Come back in June!

MK

"We expect over time that neutral rates move up"
